data.text:
"Giving back was a part of my father's philosophy of

making money. He felt a genuine sense of gratitude for

the opportunities he had, and we feel the same way

today," explains Malouf.

His political beliefs serve to reinforce his philanthropy.

"Everybody," states Malouf, "believes in helping those

truly in need, but what's the most effective way to do it?

If you believe the government ought to do it, here's what

you have: (1) a program must be set up in Washington

to function at the national, state, and local levels; (2)

people have to be hired to run these programs; (3)

massive regulations have to be published; (4) funds must

be appropriated, either through raising taxes or dcficit

spending; (5) and if, perchance, the tax dollars do finally

trickle down, they will have been substantially diluted.

"The vastly superior alternative," argues Malouf, "is to

give directly to fulfill the local needs, eliminating the

necessity of a federal program, bureaucracy, and budget

to sustain it. If you give directly to meet a local need,

you get more mileage out of your dollars."

The city, named after the Canadian River, was settled

in the 1880s and incorporated in 1887. The south fork of

the river knifes across the northern edge of the city. The

diversified economy is based on oil, agriculture, and the

raising of cattle and quarter-horses. Wild turkey, deer,

quail, and prairie chicken are nestled among the hills

overlooking the serpentine valley that extends some 40

miles west-to-east across the Panhandle to the Antelope

Hills in Oklahoma, barely visible on the distant horizon.

The land is rugged, dominated by sagebrush but beauti-

fied by the foliage of the cottonwoods in autumn.

Driving through Canadian, the average person may

perceive it to be "another bland Panhandle town," but a

closer inspection reveals that such a perception is far

from reality. There are many pockets of historical and

architectural interest in Canadian, for example:

• The Women's Christian Temperance Union building

on Main Street, erected in 1911, is the only WCTU

facility in the U.S. still locally owned and operated.

The neat, red brick building now serves the commun-

ity as a library (upper floor) and community meeting

hall (basement floor).

• The beautiful Edward Abraham Memorial Home is a

regional model for residential facilities serving senior

citizens. This facility was constructed in honor of the

younger Abraham brother who died in 1961 at the age

of 44.

• The Citadel is a showplace residence of the Dr.

Malouf Abraham, Jr. family. It was originally built in

1910 as the First Baptist Church. The renovation has

won national acclaim and publicity.

• The antiquated three-story Moody Hotel, vacant since

1960, has been renovated and refurbished into an

office complex to serve as the corporate offices for

Malouf Abraham's enterprises and other tenants.

• The picturesque 'big house' where the senior Abraham

family lived until Nahim's death in 1964, is also being

renovated by Dr. Malouf Abraham, Jr., and wife

Therese.

Malouf, a vigorous man at age 68, still works hard—

but is increasingly reflective: "During our family's 1961

trip to Lebanon, I remember looking steadily into the

eyes of a shepherd, a man about my own age, and I

kept wondering if—had not my father come to Amer-

ica—that might have been me."

In 1987 the citizens of Canadian, Texas will collec-

tively throw their hats in the air to celebrate the city's

centennial. In so doing, they will also be saluting the

memory of Nahim and Alia Abraham, pioneer builders

of their community.

Still very much alive in this small Panhandle city is the

daring and spirit that inspired a 17-year-old Lebanese

boy to leave his homeland in quest of the American

dream more than 80 years ago.

Canadian owes much to the legacy of Nahim Abra-

ham.

Mr. Burch is a development consultant and writer who lives in

Abilene, Texas.
